Research Paper One-pot synthesis of chitin-derived Co–NPs/NC catalysts: Efficient reductive N-formylation of nitro compounds to formamides Deqiong Xie Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation a Jiale Huang Investigation a Wenqian Zhai Investigation a Jing Shi Data curation b De-Li Chen Methodology Investigation a Weidong Zhu Project administration a ⁎ Fumin Zhang Supervision Project administration Conceptualization a ⁎ a Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials, Institute of Physical Chemistry, Zhejiang Normal University, Jinhua 321004, PR China Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials Institute of Physical Chemistry Zhejiang Normal University Jinhua 321004 PR China aKey Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials, Institute of Physical Chemistry, Zhejiang Normal University, Jinhua 321004, People's Republic of China b Department of Criminal Science and Technology, Nanjing Police University, Nanjing 210023, PR China Department of Criminal Science and Technology Nanjing Police University Nanjing 210023 PR China bDepartment of Criminal Science and Technology, Nanjing Police University, Nanjing 210023, People's Republic of China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Chitin, a nitrogen-rich biopolymer, serves as an ideal precursor for synthesizing nitrogen-doped carbon (NC)-supported metal catalysts, enhancing catalytic performance and promoting sustainability by utilizing widely available biomass resources. In this paper, Co nanoparticles (NPs) with different cobalt loadings were anchored onto NC via a one-pot pyrolysis of chitin and CoCl₂ at 1073 K under inert conditions. This synthetic pathway significantly enhanced the interaction between Co–NPs and NC compared to catalysts synthesized by the traditional impregnation method. Consequently, the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC catalyst demonstrated outstanding catalytic efficacy (conversion of 99.7 %, selectivity of 99.9 %, and TOF of 123 h⁻¹) and stability, maintaining performance over at least seven cycles in the reductive N-formyl of nitrobenzene to N-phenylformamide, using 10-fold equivalents of formic acid as both hydrogen donor and formylating agent. The catalytic activity of this catalyst outperformed other variants, including the 0.3 %, 2.1 %, and 4.8 % Co–NPs/NC samples, along with the 1.0 % Coim/C and 1.0 % Coim/NC prepared via the conventional impregnation method. Both basic nitrogen atoms and Co–Nx sites played crucial roles in facilitating the one-pot reductive N-formylation, with protic NH⁺ and hydridic Co–H⁻ species suggested as active intermediates in the transfer hydrogenation reactions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords One-pot pyrolysis Co nanoparticle Reductive N-formylation Transfer hydrogenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Formamides are crucial intermediates in the synthesis of pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, dyes, and fragrances [1]. Additionally, formamides serve as industrial solvents and function as Lewis bases in various catalytic systems [2]. In peptide synthesis, the formyl group is essential for protecting amines [3]. Given the broad applications of formamides, advancing efficient synthesis methods for these compounds is a research priority. Historically, N-formamides were synthesized by reacting anilines with hazardous formylating agents, including chloral, phosgene, carbon monoxide, and acetic formic anhydrides [4–6], often resulting in low atom economy and substantial waste. Recent studies have concentrated on the N-formylation of anilines employing transition-metal catalysts. Specifically, catalytic N-formylation using carbon dioxide as a carbonyl source, combined with reductants such as hydrogen, silanes, or boranes, has been successfully conducted with metal-based catalysts [7–10]. However, these methods often rely on costly, complex noble metal complexes that necessitate harsh conditions and generate substantial by-products [11], thereby reducing atom efficiency. Aryl amines, frequently used as precursors for N-aryl formamides, are typically synthesized via nitroarene reduction catalyzed by transition metals under high hydrogen pressure [12–15]. Thus, exploring alternative, cost-effective approaches using base metals to efficiently and selectively synthesize formamides from affordable, readily available nitroarenes is an urgent research need. Formic acid (FA), with a hydrogen content of 4.4 wt%, presents a viable alternative to hydrogen gas (H₂). Produced from biomass, it is an economical, safe, and easily manageable liquid hydrogen donor [16]. Additionally, FA and its derivatives act as formylating agents in the N-formylation reactions of anilines, which can be conducted under mild conditions. Consequently, numerous researchers are exploring the potential of substituting precious metal catalysts with alternatives derived from transition metals [17,18]. Among these alternatives, metal-nitrogen-doped carbon catalysts (M-N-C, where M may be Co, Fe, or Ni) have garnered significant attention for their similarity to noble metal catalysts, enabling various organocatalytic reactions [19–23]. Several highly efficient M-N-C catalysts have been developed for the selective hydrogenation of functionalized nitroarenes, utilizing FA as a hydrogen source [19–23]. Research indicates that nitrogen-doped carbon shells can significantly enhance both the catalytic activity and selectivity of these catalysts through synergistic interaction with Co nanoparticles (NPs) [22]. Additionally, these carbon shells shield the active Co–NPs from acidic degradation [23]. Traditionally, metal-ligand complexes or pre-synthesized metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are employed as precursors for M-N-C catalysts, prepared through pyrolysis [24–26]. Nonetheless, excessive precursor usage may result in unstable cobalt oxides or exposed Co–NPs under acidic conditions, requiring further acid or base treatments to prevent adverse interactions between active cobalt species and FA. This added processing complicates the overall procedure and raises environmental concerns. Alternatively, simpler organic materials or biomass combined with cobalt salts have been directly pyrolyzed to produce catalysts, though these often require acid treatments or show limited catalytic activity [27,28]. Thus, a key challenge persists in developing highly efficient, acid-resistant catalysts via a simple, cost-effective, and environmentally friendly approach. Chitin, the Earth's second-most abundant biopolymer after cellulose, is a nitrogen-rich material primarily sourced from the exoskeletons of insects and crustaceans. Its abundance, affordability, and eco-friendly attributes make natural chitin an ideal candidate for various applications [29–32]. Furthermore, chitin's surface is rich in oxygen- and nitrogen-containing functional groups, enabling effective chelation with metal ions. As a result, chitin shows promising potential as a carbon and nitrogen source for synthesizing metal NPs/NC catalysts [33–36], capitalizing on its strong coordination ability to enhance both catalytic performance and stability. This study introduces a straightforward method to synthesize nitrogen-doped carbon-supported cobalt nanoparticles (Co–NPs/NC) catalysts with variable cobalt concentrations. This is accomplished through in situ pyrolysis of chitin and CoCl₂ precursors in an inert atmosphere. The catalytic efficiency of Co–NPs/NC catalysts was assessed in the transfer hydrogenation of nitroarenes to produce formamide derivatives, with FA acting as both the hydrogen donor and formylating agent. For comparison, Coim/C and Coim/NC catalysts were prepared using traditional post-loading method, including wet impregnation followed by hydrogen reduction. These comparisons underscore the enhanced activity and stability of Co–NPs/NC catalysts in transfer hydrogenation processes. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst synthesis Preparation of 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC: A single-step pyrolysis method was applied to synthesize 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC. Initially, 2.0 g of chitin was mixed with 15 mL of ethanol and stirred to form a uniform slurry. Subsequently, 1.6 mL of a CoCl2 aqueous solution (10 mg/mL) was gradually added. The mixture was sonicated for 20 min, followed by 12 h of continuous stirring at room temperature. The solvent was then evaporated at 333 K, and the resulting solid was dried overnight at 393 K. The resulting powder (0.4 g) was placed in a tubular furnace, heated to 1073 K at a rate of 5 K/min under a nitrogen flow of 80 mL/min, and held at this temperature for 2 h, then allowed to cool naturally. ICP-AES analysis determined a cobalt content of 1.0 wt% in the composite. For Co–NPs/NC composites with Co loadings of 0.3 %, 2.1 %, and 4.8 %, the same procedure was followed, with adjustments in CoCl2 solution volumes to 0.8 mL, 3.2 mL, and 8 mL, respectively, as the metal precursor. A pure NC support was prepared using the same method without the inclusion of CoCl2. Preparation of 1.0 % Coim/C: The 1.0 % Coim/C catalyst was produced by impregnating 0.5 g of activated carbon (C) with 1.1 mL of a CoCl2 solution (10 mg/mL) and then dried at 383 K for 12 h The sample was subsequently calcined at 673 K for 2 h under a nitrogen environment, with a 5 K/min heating rate. Before testing for activity, the catalyst underwent reduction at 673 K for 2 h in a 20 % hydrogen and 80 % nitrogen gas mixture at 80 mL/min flow rate. The 1.0 % Coim/NC catalyst was synthesized using the same method but employed NC as the support material. 2.2 Catalyst performance test The catalytic performance of various catalysts in the transfer hydrogenation of nitroaromatics, using FA as the hydrogen source, was tested in a 25 mL Schlenk tube. The procedure began by dissolving 0.5 mmol of a nitroaromatic compound in 3 mL of toluene as the solvent, followed by the addition of 10 mg of catalyst, which was dispersed by ultrasonication for 5 min. After sealing, the reactor was submerged in a temperature-controlled oil bath set to 373 K and stirred at 700 rpm. The reaction mixture was purged five times with nitrogen to remove residual air. FA (5 mmol) was then injected to initiate the reaction. Aliquots of 0.2 mL were taken at specific intervals, immediately filtered through a 0.22 μm membrane to remove catalyst particles and halt the reaction, and analyzed using gas chromatography (Shimadzu, GC-2014) equipped with an FID and a capillary column (HP-5, 30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 μm). Product identification was confirmed via GC (Agilent Technologies 5975C). Each experiment was performed in triplicate, yielding a reproducibility of ± 3 %. Post-reaction, the 1 % Co–NPs/NC catalyst was recovered by centrifugation, washed three times with toluene and anhydrous methanol, and dried at 343 K for reuse. Turnover frequency (TOF) is defined as the number of N-phenylformamide molecules formed per Co active site in the catalyst per hour. The calculation formula is as follows: (2) T O F = n n i t r o b e n z e n e * a * b n C o * D s * t D s is the dispersion of Co in the catalyst, n nitrobenzene and n Co are the mole numbers of nitrobenzene and Co, respectively. a is the conversion of nitrobenzene expressed by t (time), b is the selectivity for N-phenylformamide. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst preparation and characterization Scheme 1 illustrates the mechanism involved in the formation of Co–NPs/NC catalysts. Initially, 2 g of chitin was combined with 15 mL of ethanol and stirred for 30 min to create a uniform slurry. Subsequently, 1.6 mL of a CoCl2 solution (10 mg/mL) was gradually added to the mixture while maintaining vigorous stirring. The functional groups in the chitin structure, such as –OH and –NH2, act as anchoring sites, effectively capturing and stabilizing Co cations, thereby ensuring an even distribution of Co species throughout the chitin matrix. After high-temperature annealing, the Co(II)-chitin precursors are converted into NC-supported Co–NPs catalysts, characterized by a high dispersion of Co–NPs. To investigate the impact of Co content on the NC structure of the derived catalysts, XRD patterns were recorded for all samples, as shown in Fig. 1 . The XRD pattern of chitin exhibited at least four prominent peaks at 2θ values of 9.38°, 12.82°, 19.33°, and 26.50°, corresponding to the (020), (021), (110), and (130) planes, respectively (Fig. 1a) [37]. During high-temperature pyrolysis, most diffraction peaks corresponding to chitin were eliminated, resulting in a broad peak observed in the Co–NPs/NC samples within the 20° to 30° range, corresponding to the interplanar diffraction of the (002) plane in graphitized carbon [37,38]. However, the (130) plane characteristic of chitin remained (Fig. 1b). This observation indicates that all Co–NPs/NC catalysts derived from Co(II)-chitin mixtures display a relatively disordered graphitized carbon structure. Furthermore, no peaks associated with Co–NPs were detected in the 0.3 % and 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC samples, likely due to the low loading and small size of the species in these catalysts. However, as the Co loading increased to 2.1 %, a weak peak appeared at 2θ = 44.2°, indicating the in-plane diffraction of the (111) facets of Co NPs [39]. An additional increase in Co loading to 4.8 % resulted in an intensified weak diffraction peak at 2θ = 44.2°, suggesting higher Co loading facilitates the formation of Co species with larger particle sizes. Additionally, another weak diffraction at 2θ = 51.5° was observed in the 4.8 % Co–NPs/NC sample, corresponding to the (200) diffraction of Co NPs [40]. Collectively, these findings indicate that Co content significantly influences dispersion of Co NPs within the derived catalysts. The porosity of Co–NPs/NC samples with varying cobalt loadings was evaluated using the nitrogen adsorption-desorption technique. All derived samples exhibited clear characteristics of Type IV isotherms (Fig. 2 a), as classified by the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry [41]. Hysteresis loops were observed in all four isotherms, attributed to capillary condensation at higher pressures (P/P₀ between 0.4 and 1), indicating the presence of mesopores within these Co(II)-chitin precursors-derived catalysts. Additionally, the adsorbed nitrogen volumes significantly increased at relatively low pressures (0 < P/P₀ < 0.1), indicating the presence of micropores in these catalysts. The BET specific surface area of the Co–NPs/NC catalysts increased steadily from 210 to 291 m²/g as the cobalt loading increased from 0.3 % to 1.0 % by mass, then decreased sharply to 218 m²/g at 4.8 % cobalt loading (Table 1 ). Notably, the BET surface area of the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC sample surpasses that of other counterparts, suggesting that the metal salts function as chemical activators during pyrolysis [33], thereby facilitating an increase in surface area, although an optimal dosage is necessary. A similar trend was observed in the pore volumes of the Co–NPs/NC samples, suggesting that an optimal amount of cobalt salt functions as a chemical activator during pyrolysis, enhancing both surface area and pore volume. The pore size distribution showed the coexistence of micropores and mesopores (approximately 0.8–1.2 nm and 2–10 nm, respectively) across all samples (Fig. 2b), as determined by the DFT method. These results indicate that chitin is an effective precursor for synthesizing NC materials with an integrated microporous and mesoporous composite structure. The morphology of various Co–NPs/NC catalysts was examined using SEM, as illustrated in Fig. S1. All samples exhibited coarse surfaces resembling biochars, indicating the degradation of chitin structures during the high-temperature pyrolysis process. Additional structural information was obtained through TEM and HRTEM characterization, as presented in Fig. 3 . Almost no distinct Co–NPs were observed in the 0.3 % Co–NPs/NC and 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC samples (Fig. 3a, b, d, and e), primarily due to their relatively low loadings and high dispersion. In contrast, well-dispersed Co–NPs were distinctly detected in the 2.1 % Co–NPs/NC and 4.8 % Co–NPs/NC samples (Fig. 3g, h, j, and k), with average crystallite sizes of 6.5 nm and 7.5 nm, respectively. Figs. 3f, i, and l illustrate the crystal planes of Co–NPs, with a measured crystal plane spacing of 0.204 nm [42], corresponding to the Co (111) planes. Furthermore, EDS elemental mapping was utilized to assess the elemental distribution of Co, C, and N in the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC sample. As illustrated in Fig. S2, the Co, C, and N atoms were homogeneously distributed throughout the sample, confirming the uniform dispersion of these three elements. Due to the inability to establish the dispersion of Co–NPs in the 0.3 % Co–NPs/NC and 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC samples through TEM and HRTEM analysis, CO pulse adsorption was utilized to assess the dispersion of Co–NPs and to determine their sizes across the different samples. The results of CO pulse chemisorption indicate that the dispersion of Co–NPs decreased from 83.8 % to 24.4 % as the Co loading increased from 0.3 % to 4.8 % (Table 1). Correspondingly, the diameter of Co–NPs increased from 1.3 nm for the 0.3 % Co–NPs/NC sample to 2.4 nm for the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC sample, 4.3 nm for the 2.1 % Co–NPs/NC sample, and 4.4 nm for the 4.8 % Co–NPs/NC sample. The discrepancy in Co–NP sizes measured by CO pulse chemisorption and TEM may arise because the former reflects an overall statistical average, while the latter provides a localized measurement. Fig. 4 displays the Raman spectra of various Co–NPs/NC catalysts. In each sample, the d-band, around 1350 cm⁻¹ (corresponding to the vibrations of sp³-hybridized carbon atoms in defects or disordered carbon), and the G-band, near 1580 cm⁻¹ (associated with sp²-hybridized carbon atoms in graphitic hexagonal structures) [43], were observed. The relative intensities of the d-band (ID) and G-band (IG) serve as a valuable metric for assessing defect sites within the carbon material [44], potentially impacting catalytic performance by modifying the local electronic environment and chemical behavior. The ID/IG ratios for the samples ranged from 0.91 to 0.98, indicating that the NC, derived from chitin pyrolysis with different Co loadings, exhibits a similar concentration of defects within its carbon structure. Fig. 5 a illustrates the XPS Co 2p3/2 spectra for Co–NPs/NC catalysts, synthesized from calcined Co(II)-chitin precursors with varying concentrations of cobalt. The spectra for the Co 2p3/2 peak can be decomposed into three distinct peaks located at 778.6 eV, 780.2 eV, and 782.3 eV, which are attributed to metallic Co0, Co–Ox, and Co–Nx species, respectively [45], alongside a satellite peak at 786.2 eV This satellite peak, situated at 786.2 eV, is linked to the Co–O bond [46], signifying the presence of Co2+ within the Co–Ox component. The appearance of Co–Ox is due to the partial oxidation of the sample surface when exposed to air. Table S1 presents a detailed summary of the atomic percentages of Co0, Co–Ox, and Co–Nx, expressed as proportions of the total cobalt content within the catalysts. With the increase in Co concentration from 0.3 % to 4.8 % in the Co–NPs/NC system, the metallic Co° content also increased, rising from 5.9 at.% to 13.3 at.%, which aligns well with XRD results that verify the presence of metallic Co0 in samples containing 2.1 % and 48 % Co–NPs/NC. The Co–Nx species are formed through the interaction of Co with nitrogen, primarily existing as highly dispersed Co entities. The Co–Nx proportion varies between 18.4 at.% and 24.4 at.% across the catalysts, with the highest value of 24.4 at.% observed in the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC sample, as depicted in Table S1. This increase is believed to result from enhanced nitrogen volatilization driven by higher concentrations of CoCl2 in the Co(II)-chitin precursors [47]. Further evaluations indicate that the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC catalyst exhibits the most favorable catalytic performance, linked to its superior surface Co–Nx distribution. The overall cobalt content in the bulk phase of all catalysts was quantified using ICP-OES analysis, with results for both the test and control samples compiled in Table 1. The findings from ICP-AES analysis validate that the actual Co loadings in all Co–NPs/NC samples closely match the intended values set during synthesis. Fig. 5b presents the N 1 s spectral profiles for Co–NPs/NC catalysts at different Co concentrations. The deconvolution of these N 1 s spectra reveals peaks at 398.5 eV, 399.2 eV, 400.6 eV, and 401.5 eV, which correspond to pyridinic-N, Co–Nx, pyrrolic-N, and graphitic-N, respectively [48,49]. As the Co concentration in the Co–NPs/NC catalysts increased from 0.3 % to 4.8 %, the atomic fractions of pyridinic N, graphitic N, and Co–Nx were observed to decrease slightly, while pyrrolic N increased slightly (Table S2). Consistent with the Co 2p3/2 spectra outlined in Fig. 5a, the N 1 s analysis further supports the existence of Co–Nx in the Co–NPs/NC catalysts. Within these catalysts, the Co–Nx entities are derived from nitrogen configurations that coordinate with both individual Co atoms and Co nanoparticle sites. This coordination strengthens the stability of atomic Co sites and reduces the tendency for Co species to agglomerate during the pyrolysis process. 3.2 Transfer hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to N-phenylformamide Initially, the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to N-phenylformamide using FA as the hydrogen donor was selected as the model reaction, with Co–NPs/NC catalysts tested to assess the impact of varying Co loadings on catalytic performance. In the absence of a catalyst (control experiment) or when only the support (NC) or chitin alone was used, no detectable conversion of nitrobenzene was observed with 10 equivalents of FA after 270 min at 373 K (Table 2 , Entries 1–3). This observation suggests that the presence of active metal sites is crucial to initiate the hydrogen transfer process in nitrobenzene reduction. The Co–NPs/NC catalysts demonstrated significant catalytic efficiency in transforming nitrobenzene to N-phenylformamide (Entries 4–7), with the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC catalyst achieving the highest activity, reaching 99.7 % nitrobenzene conversion, 99.9 % selectivity for N-phenylformamide, and a high TOF of 123 h⁻¹ under the specified conditions. XPS analysis revealed the existence of several Co species, such as Co⁰, Co–Ox, and Co–Nx, within the Co–NPs/NC catalysts, suggesting that any of these species, or their combination, could serve as active centers. To identify the precise active site, control catalysts, 1.0 % Coim/C and 1.0 % Coim/NC, were synthesized via an impregnation method and subsequently characterized (Figs. S3–S8). Nevertheless, 1.0 % Coim/C demonstrated no activity under identical conditions, even when higher catalyst dosages and elevated temperatures were employed (Entries 8 and 9), thereby ruling out Co⁰ and Co–Ox as active sites. In contrast, 1.0 % Coim/NC exhibited limited catalytic activity and selectivity (Entry 10), likely attributable to the relatively large Co–NPs present in this sample (Fig. S7). Furthermore, both homogeneous CoCl2 and Co(NO₃)₂ were determined to be catalytically inactive in the transfer hydrogenation reaction (Entries 11 and 12), confirming that Co²⁺ cations do not contribute to the observed catalytic activity. Further XPS analysis confirmed that the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC catalyst contained a substantial amount of Co–Nx species, which were hypothesized to be the active centers for the transfer hydrogenation of nitrobenzene using FA. To validate this hypothesis, a poisoning experiment was performed. Literature reports suggests that SCN⁻ ions form stable complexes with Metal-Nx species, without deactivating metal NPs or NC supports [50]. Upon introducing SCN⁻ ions into the reaction system, the catalytic efficiency of 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC significantly dropped to 1.9 % (Entry 13). This observation indicates that SCN⁻ selectively deactivated the Co–Nx sites by binding to the metal sites and forming a sulfide complex. It is also important to highlight that the catalytic efficiency of the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC catalyst surpasses that of non-noble transition metal catalysts studied in prior research (see Table S3). Collectively, these results indicate that the Co–Nx active sites, which are well-dispersed within the NC matrix, exhibit notable catalytic activity, effectively facilitating the transfer hydrogenation of nitroarenes to N-phenylformamide in the presence of FA. In the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to N-phenylformamide, key reaction parameters—including catalyst dosage, choice of solvent, reaction temperature, and equivalents of FA—were systematically optimized using a 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC catalyst (as illustrated in Fig. 6 ). This optimization was aimed at determining the conditions that maximize the yield of the target product. Increasing the catalyst amount from 8 mg to 10 mg led to a substantial improvement in nitrobenzene conversion, raising it from 78.1 % to 99.7 %. However, further increasing the catalyst quantity to 12 mg did not show any additional improvement, indicating that 10 mg is the ideal catalyst amount (Fig. 6a). The choice of solvent is essential for effective gas-liquid-solid heterogeneous catalytic reactions [51]. Various solvents, such as methanol, water, DMF, toluene, and acetonitrile, were tested to assess their influence on the transfer hydrogenation performance of the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC catalyst. Among these, methanol, water, DMF, and acetonitrile showed relatively low conversion rates for nitrobenzene and low selectivity for N-phenylformamide. In contrast, using toluene as the solvent achieved a 99.7 % conversion of nitrobenzene and nearly 100 % selectivity for N-phenylformamide under identical conditions (Fig. 6b). As a result, toluene was identified as the optimal solvent for further catalytic transfer hydrogenation experiments. The enhanced catalytic performance observed with toluene is likely due to its capacity to improve the adsorption and activation of substrate molecules [52], thereby facilitating their transformation. Additionally, increasing the reaction temperature from 363 K to 373 K significantly boosted the yield of N-phenylformamide, rising from 59.6 % to 99.7 % (Fig. 6c), highlighting the pivotal role of temperature in maximizing product yield. Consequently, 373 K was identified as the optimal reaction temperature for this reaction. Further experiments conducted for control purposes reveal that the reductive N-formylation of nitroarenes occurs through a stepwise mechanism [53,54]. Initially, the nitro group undergoes reduction to an amine, followed by formylation to yield N-phenylformamide, with FA acting as both the reducing and formylating agent. Introducing 1 equivalents of FA into the toluene solution for 270 min at a temperature of 373 K resulted in only 13.8 % hydrogenation of nitrobenzene. The main product formed was aniline, with a selectivity of 94.4 %, while N-phenylformamide exhibited a selectivity of just 5.6 %. Upon increasing the amount of FA from 2 to 8 equivalents, under the same conditions, the conversion of nitrobenzene surged from 26.9 % to 90.4 %. This also led to an increase in the selectivity for N-phenylformamide, which rose from 38 % to 99.7 %, while the selectivity for aniline decreased from 62 % to 0.3 % (Fig. 6d). Ultimately, using 10 equivalents of FA resulted in a 99.7 % conversion of nitrobenzene and an outstanding 99.9 % selectivity for N-phenylformamide under optimized conditions. Fig. 7 a depicts the time-dependent concentration changes of reactants and products for the reductive N-formylation of nitrobenzene using FA, catalyzed by 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC under optimal conditions. The substrate nitrobenzene depleted rapidly within 270 min, while the selectivity for N-phenylformamide showed minimal reduction as nitrobenzene conversion proceeded. Throughout almost the entire 270-min conversion period, N-phenylformamide selectivity consistently exceeded 99.7 %. Extending the reaction time to 360 min did not alter the selectivity of N-phenylformamide. Additionally, a small quantity of the intermediate hydrogenation product, aniline, was detected. These results suggest that catalytic hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to aniline, facilitated by 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC in the presence of excess FA, proceeds considerably faster than the subsequent N-formylation stage. The reusability of the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC catalyst was thoroughly assessed. As depicted in Fig. 7b, both the nitrobenzene conversion and the selectivity for N-phenylformamide remained consistently high across seven successive cycles, illustrating the remarkable durability of the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC catalyst. Notably, after the initial cycle of the transfer hydrogenation process, the cobalt concentration in the reaction mixture was found to be below the detection limits of ICP-AES, suggesting that Co species were not leached during the reaction. Furthermore, no notable variations were detected in the XRD pattern of the used catalyst (Fig. S9). TEM and HRTEM imaging further corroborated the stable distribution of Co–NPs and the structural integrity of the NC support (Fig. S10). The outstanding recyclability of the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC is likely due to the encapsulation of Co–NPs within the NC matrix, which minimizes the interaction between Co–NPs and protons. Additionally, the incorporation of nitrogen enhances electron transfer, leading to increased electron density around the cobalt, thereby boosting the catalyst's resistance to FA. 3.3 Reaction mechanism for the reductive N-formylation of nitrobenzene The surface basicity and acidity of 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC and 1.0 % Coim/C were evaluated using CO₂-TPD and NH₃-TPD analyses. As depicted in Fig. 8 a, the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC sample displayed a distinct peak centered around 370 K, along with a broader peak ranging from 480 to 790 K. These peaks correspond to CO₂ desorption based on mass spectra analysis, indicating the presence of both weak and strong base sites on the catalyst surface [55]. In contrast, for 1.0 % Coim/C, the CO₂ desorption signal is significantly weaker across the temperature range of 330 K to 850 K, indicating a limited number of accessible base sites in this sample. Similarly, the NH₃ desorption signal for 1.0 % Coim/C is almost negligible (Fig. 8b), while 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC exhibits prominent NH₃ desorption peaks between 380 and 790 K, confirming the enrichment of acidic sites in this catalyst. The findings indicate that 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC possesses a substantial amount of both acidic and basic sites on its surface. Furthermore, XPS analysis indicates that the Co–Nx content in 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC is the highest among the tested catalysts. Thus, the synergistic catalysis between acidic and basic sites and the Co–Nx centers within 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC markedly enhances its transfer hydrogenation activity. Previous studies indicated that transfer hydrogenation reactions involving FA typically require a base [56]. However, our catalytic system does not conform to this trend. We hypothesized that the nitrogen atoms in the NC support, possessing lone pair electrons, functioned as the base. To test this hypothesis, we conducted a control experiment using 10 equivalents of H3PO4 and 10 equivalents of FA. As anticipated, the conversion of nitrobenzene decreased significantly to 6.0 % (refer to Table S4, Entry 1). This reduction in activity is likely attributable to the neutralization of the pyridine nitrogen in the NC support, which functions as a base in the catalyst to capture H+ from FA, by phosphoric acid, resulting in the deactivation of the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC catalyst. Furthermore, when H2 was utilized as the hydrogen source under the other identical conditions, no reaction occurred, even after extending the duration to 24 h, indicating that nitrobenzene reduction occurs via transfer hydrogenation with FA rather than direct hydrogenation with H2. Moreover, treating FA in toluene at 373 K with 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC maintained a constant reactor pressure, suggesting that no gas was generated. GC analysis of the gaseous products confirmed the absence of H2, thereby ruling out hydrogen generation from FA decomposition. Importantly, the inclusion of alkaline additives, such as triethylamine, ammonium hydroxide, tert‑butylamine, or sodium hydroxide, significantly impaired the performance of the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC catalyst (refer to Table S4, Entries 2–4). These bases appeared to inhibit the reaction rather than facilitate it. Two potential explanations for this phenomenon are that these electron-donating species may compete with formate ions (HCOO⁻) for adsorption sites on Co–Nx, or that the addition of alkaline substances disrupts the synergistic interaction between the doped nitrogen species and Co–Nx by competitively capturing protons [57]. These results underscore the critical roles of both Co–Nx and nitrogen species in facilitating FA transfer hydrogenation. Based on the preceding analysis and conclusions from relevant literature, a reaction mechanism for the reductive N-formylation of nitrobenzene to N-phenylformamide is proposed and depicted in Scheme 2 [58]. In this mechanism, nitrogen atoms in the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC catalyst function as basic sites that efficiently capture protons (H+). These nitrogen atoms specifically interact with H+ from HCOOH, resulting in NH+ formation. The low d-electron density of cobalt offers vacant orbitals that enable HCCO– to coordinate with Co atoms, producing a Co-formate intermediate. This intermediate subsequently releases CO2, leading to the formation of Co–H−. Due to their high electronegativity and coordination potential, nitrogen atoms interact synergistically with Co–Nx, enhancing the bonding between Co and the oxygen atoms in nitrobenzene. Subsequently, hydrogen atoms from Co–H− and NH+ react with nitrobenzene, enabling aniline production via a transfer hydrogenation approach. Notably, electron transfer within the Co–Nx bonds imparts a slight positive charge to Co atoms, enhancing their adsorption capacity. Ultimately, aniline reacts spontaneously with HCOOH, forming N-phenylformamide without requiring a catalyst. Furthermore, GC–MS analysis confirmed aniline as an intermediate, validating the progression of transfer hydrogenation from nitrobenzene to aniline and then to N-phenylformamide. In this reaction, both Co–H− and NH+ serve as hydrogen donors for the nitro group's transfer hydrogenation, and their formation resembles the heterolytic cleavage of H2. Notably, the involvement of a proton (H+) and a hydride (H−) is frequently observed in the reduction of polar bonds, such as CO and CN, while homolytic H2 cleavage is typically more effective for non-polar bond reduction [59,60]. Consequently, the formation of NH+ and Co–H− is well-justified, as these are the active species critical for the transfer hydrogenation of nitro groups. Additional experiments with the inclusion of butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT, 0.5 mmol) and/or 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidoxyl (TEMPO, 0.5 mmol) as radical scavengers demonstrated no effect on the catalytic outcomes (Table S5), suggesting that the catalytic transfer hydrogenation pathway does not involve radical species. 3.4 Substrate universality over 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC The synthesized 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC catalyst was further evaluated for broader applicability by examining its role in the reductive N-formylation of various nitro compounds, as demonstrated in Table 3 . Results indicated that this catalyst consistently facilitated efficient hydrogenation of a wide range of functionalized nitroarenes, irrespective of their electron-donating or electron-withdrawing groups, yielding corresponding formamides in high to excellent yields (Entries 1–10). Notably, the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC catalyst also achieved complete conversion of halogen-substituted nitrobenzenes, producing substantial amounts of formamides without detectable dehalogenation (Entry 11). Furthermore, the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC catalyst was effective in the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of sterically hindered nitroarenes, such as 2,6-dimethylnitrobenzene, 3-methyl-2-nitroanisole, and 1-nitronaphthalene. By extending the reaction time to 8 h, all substrates were efficiently converted into the desired products (Entries 12–14), suggesting that steric hindrance does not significantly impact the performance of the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC catalyst. 4 Conclusion A cost-effective and sustainable synthesis method was developed for producing NC-stabilized Co–NP catalysts through the direct pyrolysis of Co(II)-chitin precursors. This approach enables the uniform integration of Co–NPs into the NC framework, leveraging renewable chitin as a dual source of carbon and nitrogen. By adjusting the concentration of cobalt precursors, both the Co particle size and the content of Co–Nx species within the NC matrix can be finely tuned, which is critical to the catalytic performance of Co–NPs/NC catalysts in the transfer hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to N-phenylformamide, where formic acid serves as both the hydrogen donor and formylating agent. Experimental results show that the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC catalyst, characterized by a high concentration of uniformly distributed Co–Nx and nitrogen species, exhibits a strong synergistic effect, resulting in complete nitrobenzene conversion to N-phenylformamide in toluene at 373 K within 270 min. Furthermore, this direct pyrolysis method effectively minimizes the migration and leaching of Co–NPs from the carbon matrix, enhancing catalyst stability. This scalable technique offers considerable potential for the mass production of sustainable Co–NPs/NC catalysts, making them viable for a wide range of industrial applications. coredata.dc:description: Chitin, a nitrogen-rich biopolymer, serves as an ideal precursor for synthesizing nitrogen-doped carbon (NC)-supported metal catalysts, enhancing catalytic performance and promoting sustainability by utilizing widely available biomass resources. In this paper, Co nanoparticles (NPs) with different cobalt loadings were anchored onto NC via a one-pot pyrolysis of chitin and CoCl₂ at 1073 K under inert conditions. This synthetic pathway significantly enhanced the interaction between Co–NPs and NC compared to catalysts synthesized by the traditional impregnation method. Consequently, the 1.0 % Co–NPs/NC catalyst demonstrated outstanding catalytic efficacy (conversion of 99.7 %, selectivity of 99.9 %, and TOF of 123 h⁻¹) and stability, maintaining performance over at least seven cycles in the reductive N-formyl of nitrobenzene to N-phenylformamide, using 10-fold equivalents of formic acid as both hydrogen donor and formylating agent. The catalytic activity of this catalyst outperformed other variants, including the 0.3 %, 2.1 %, and 4.8 % Co–NPs/NC samples, along with the 1.0 % Coim/C and 1.0 % Coim/NC prepared via the conventional impregnation method. Both basic nitrogen atoms and Co–Nx sites played crucial roles in facilitating the one-pot reductive N-formylation, with protic NH⁺ and hydridic Co–H⁻ species suggested as active intermediates in the transfer hydrogenation reactions.
